abstract: For MSO\(_2\)-expressible problems like Edge Dominating Set or Hamiltonian Cycle, it was open for a long time whether there is an algorithm which given a clique-width k-expression of an n-vertex graph runs in time \(f(k) \cdot n^{\mathcal {O}(1)}\) for some function f. Recently, Fomin et al. (SIAM. J. Computing, 2014) presented several lower bounds; for instance, there are no \(f(k)\cdot n^{o(k)}\)-time algorithms for Edge Dominating Set and for Hamiltonian Cycle unless the Exponential Time Hypothesis (ETH) fails. They also provided an algorithm running in time \(n^{\mathcal {O}(k)}\) for Edge Dominating Set, but left open whether Hamiltonian Cycle can be solved in time \(n^{\mathcal {O}(k)}\).
meta: Conference: Workshop on Algorithms and Data Structures
